message: What are some great books that every entrepreneurs should read?
+1 for rework. although I prefer their previous book 'getting real' but it's more catered to tech / software / apps
David Cohen's "Do More Faster: TechStars Lessons to Accelerate Your Startup". I'm about halfway through it and there's a lot of great lessons there.
Hi! You should take a look at "Rework", co-written by DHH. I finished it few days ago, and I think it's a great book if you want to start something.
Also, check out "Business Model Generation" by Osterwalder & Pigneur
delivering happiness by Tony hsieh of zappos. my personal favorite
Thanks @unwrangle, interested by 'getting real'. It seems web oriented, though. What do you think?

@benjipetit web oriented kinda, but more towards web app than website. like if that's your world, great read. if you're a straight up business / finance guy, you might feel alienated on some (if not most) chapters
http://www.foundersatwork.com/
founders at work for stories of startups in their early days
e.g. if your business is going to be posted on 'hacker news' definitely give it a go
http://www.guykawasaki.com/enchantment/
http://www.quora.com/Book-Recommendations/What-books-should-entrepreneurs-read?q=what+book+
How to Do More Faster by the Tech Stars
+1 for Osterwalder, also Blank's Four Steps to the Epiphany, the Zappo's book.  Made to Stick. Crossing the Chasm...  And then it starts to depend ....
Read Peopleware and The Mythical Man-Month to gain some insight on managing a technical team.

Guy Kawasaki's 'The Art of the Start' and 'Reality Check' are full of practical advice. 'Founders at Work' also made for an interesting read. I have started with Rework a couple of days ago and it does seem pretty nice! I'd also suggest reading 'Rich Dad Poor Dad'.
do more faster
founders at work is also pretty good
built to last, innovator's dilemma, and crossing the chasm are in our top three
The New Cool

The Innovator's Dilemma is an absolute must read for any entrepreneur bc whether you're aware of the "rules" or theories put forth within the book or not, they are taking place in and around your industry.  The awesome part is that it'll give you confidence in your ability to disrupt entrenched organizations because it goes on to explain why these organizations miss the boat on new ideas: they're not organized in a way that would allow them to see the opportunity or if they do their cost structure prevents the opportunity from being profitable to them.
Atlas Shrugged.
Don't make me think, Pull (for those who are not up to speed on semantic web) ,Predictably Irrational, Power, Free (wonder why that hasn't been mentioned yet, such a must read)
and here is a great reading list: http://platformsandnetworks.blogspot.com/2011/01/launching-tech-ventures-part-iv.html
Atlas Shrugged, the facebook effect, linchpin, the moon is a harsh mistress - and introducing autodesk 3ds max but I don't think that's what you had in mind when you asked :P
I usually read lots of books at once and switch between them to keep it interesting. Kinda like watching TV series
Rework is great as mentioned previously. Rich Dad Poor Dad, Delivering Happiness, Toilet Paper Entrepreneur.
UnMarketing. Completely changed the way I look at customers and relationships. Highly recommended! PS the author is really hilarious and don't miss out on the footnotes :-P
@benjipetit is that the one by 37signals?
The Rockefeller Habits by Verne Harnish
I've been reading: Power: why some people have it and others don't
hackers and painters
business model generation
Facebook Era
Rework
just read "Delivering Happiness" and now reading "Reality Check" and "Enchantment" by Guy Kawasaki
Read "48 laws of power"
Read "Getting Real" and currently reading "The 4 hours workweek" by Tim Ferriss
Crush it. Gary vaynerchuck
The Longevity Project. I have actually read almost ALL the books above. Bless Audible.
I'm reading The Art of Living by Epectitus. My suggestions are Duct Tape Marketing, Poke The Box, Do The Work, The E-Myth, The Richest Man in Babylon, Rich Dad Poor Dad.
The Knack by Norm Brodsky & Bo Burlingham . The best entrepreneurship book that I've read so far (  after reading a lot ) Norm & Bo have the Inc. magazine Street Smart column
Derek Sivers' book collection with summaries would help a lot as well. http://sivers.org/book
@bahadircambel Can't believe I forgot that. Sivers is a great resource. I'll have to check out The Knack.
